title: 107_hr631
content: The Act may be cited as the "Project Apollo Commemorative Coin Act of 2001". Congress finds that Project Apollo was a significant milestone in the history of the United States, demonstrating technological and economic strength during the cold war. It was an engineering triumph that achieved the policy goals set by President Kennedy, advancing rocket technology in just 9 years. The Apollo flights, with 78,000 pounds of thrust, were a major achievement allowing the world to see Earth in a new way. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury shall mint $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins in commemoration of the 35th anniversary of the Apollo 11 landing. The coins will have specific weights, diameters, and compositions, and will be legal tender. The Secretary may obtain silver for minting coins from any available source, including stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of coins minted under this Act will commemorate the 35th anniversary of the Apollo 11 lunar landing with specific inscriptions and symbols. The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with relevant committees. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility starting on January 1, 2004, and ending on December 31, 2004. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, surcharges, and costs of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders received before January 1, 2004 will also receive a discount. The Secretary will add a surcharge to the sale of coins minted under the Act, with $35 per coin for the $5 coin and $10 per coin for the $1 coin. Proceeds from the surcharges will be promptly paid to the National Air and Space Museum for collecting, exhibiting, and caring for objects related to Project Apollo, as well as documenting and researching the mission. The National Air and Space Museum of the Smithsonian Institution will be audited for the amounts received under Project Apollo. SEC. 8. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES: The Secretary must ensure minting coins does not cost the government. Payment for coins requires full payment, security, or a guarantee from a depository institution.
